Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Small: Multimodal Technology Tools for Universal Access to STEM Education under the Common Core Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Given the importance of interpreting data, educators have made the teaching of graph concepts a core component of primary and secondary mathematics education. Unfortunately, the visual nature of a typical number line or graph presents a major disability for those with visual impairment. In current practice in the United States, blind students learn graphs with tactile graphics, which often represent a graph using raised dots (similar to Braille) embossed on paper. Tactile graphics are useful and have their place, but are increasingly marginal for two reasons. First, most visually impaired students now are in "mainstream" classes with their sighted peers. Mainstreaming can be beneficial in many ways, but makes it less convenient to provide alternative formats to the student; furthermore, teachers and other students will typically be unable to read Braille. Second, many classrooms are using computers for learning mathematics and graphs. Tactile graphics are generally not compatible with computers, and the very few current tools that are compatible are rudimentary or extremely expensive.

On a standard desktop computer, a natural alternative to visuals is audio. The use of auditory displays for mathematical data and graphs is not a new concept, however much still needs to be done in order to make these auditory graphs useful in the school curriculum. In this project, the PI seeks to address this need by exploring the upcoming Common Core Standards for the teaching of graphs in middle school classrooms and establishing a software system to allow visually impaired and sighted middle school students to author and explore graphs using sound. The software system will go through an ecological validation process based on the identified goals and operations of the Common Core Standards, and will include optimal auditory display designs based on the PI's findings from planned auditory graph perception experiments in multiple data sets and conveying concepts such as uncertainty.

Broader Impacts: This project opens a whole new field within assistive technology, making software-based accommodations possible and effective in the classroom. Students with vision loss stand to directly gain increased access to STEM materials from project outcomes; a solid STEM education will increase employability, which in turn will positively impact general income levels and quality of life for the members of this community. More broadly, however, it is clear that nearly all persons will benefit from appropriately designed and validated multimodal information displays. Thus, the background scientific knowledge that will be gained from this research will have foundational utility not only in this field but in many other disciplines as well, while the advances in curriculum-driven auditory graphing tools should lead to all manner of new uses for the technology in the field of education, HCI and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As an overview, this project focused on making STEM content more accessible, particularly for blind and low-vision learners. We used a variety of methods, including laboratory-based research, field studies, software and curriculum development, and evaluation in real classrooms with teachers and visually impaired students.

Some of the specific activies were:

* We completed a series of studies aimed at understanding how multiple data sets can be represented at the same time. We studied timbre and panning as stream segregation techniques. This first experiment was conducted with basic graphs designed around common graph families, derived from curriculum goals. This was expanded to include data from weather measurements, which are very useful in studying sonification and STEM, since the concepts in weather (speed, temperature, pressure, etc.) are common in STEM.

* We completed a series of studies to assess the effectiveness of various methods for displaying uncertainty in an auditory graph, similar to the way error bars represent unvertainty in a visual graph. Using filtered noise was an effective and easily learned way to use sound to display uncertainty about a data point's exact value (equivalent to visual error bars).

* The GNIE (Graphs and Numberline Interactive Exploration) software tool was further extended and improved to support curriculum-based math problems. An iterative development process allowed for substantial improvements, based on feedback from students and teachers. Notably, we improved the functionality for teachers to develop tests, archive questions, and provide feedback to student responses. We also began to implement advanced HTML5 features, and also began to develop a web-based version of the software.

* The GNIE software was again deployed at the a school for the blind, and thoroughly evaluated using in-depth field study and ethnographic methods. This led to considerable data about how such a technology can impact a classroom and the way learning happens there. It also led to many additional improvements to the GNIE system. We focused this evaluation on the teacher's needs first, then on the needs/work of the students.

* We began a series of studies to investigate using weather concepts to teach STEM concepts. For example, the common but abstract STEM topic of velocity (speed plus direction) can be taught to blind learners through the concept of wind. Students can understand that wind comes from a certain direction, with a certain speed, because they have felt it; they can then use that experience to generalize teh concept of velocity.

* We began to prototype a fully accessible mobile app for weather, which was designed from the ground up to be accessible, and which presents the weather information that a blind user needs, in teh order needed.

There have been many important outcomes from this project: Research results relating to the experiments have been published in peer-reviewed journals and refereed conferences. Two PhD dissertations have been completed in relation to this project, with anohter two in progress. Many Masters students have conducted research and development projects in relation to the project. Software has been developed and iteratively refined, then made available for download or mobilie installation. A number of students have had extensive research experience and training. A textbook on how to teach mathematics to blind students has been tranlated into Braille and into electronic formats in order to make it accessible to blind and low vision readers.
